proof:
We begin by partitioning the set of vertices $V$ into two sets. Let $P$ be the set of vertices with a degree of at most $b$, formally $P := \{v \in V : \deg(v) \leq b\}$. We then define $Q$ to be the complement of this set, $Q := V \setminus P$. This constitutes a partition of $V$ because each vertex belongs to one and only one of these two sets.

Next, we will prove the bound on the subgraph induced by $P$, denoted $G[P]$. For any vertex $v$ in the set $P$, its degree in the graph $G$ is, by definition, no more than $b$. Since $G[P]$ is a subgraph of $G$, the degree of any vertex in $G[P]$ cannot exceed its degree in $G$. Thus, the degree of $v$ in $G[P]$ is also at most $b$. From this, it follows that the maximum degree of the subgraph $G[P]$ is bounded by $b$, so $\Delta(G[P]) \leq b$.

Now, we will establish the bound on the size of $Q$. We use the well-known property that the number of edges is equivalent to half the sum of all vertex degrees. This allows us to write the following series of relations:
$$ m = \frac{1}{2} \sum_{v \in V} \deg(v) \geq \frac{1}{2} \sum_{v \in V \setminus P} \deg(v) \geq \frac{1}{2} \sum_{v \in Q} b = \frac{1}{2} |Q| \cdot b. $$
By rearranging this inequality to solve for $|Q|$, we obtain the result $|Q| \leq \frac{2m}{b}$.
